bibl.title: Telegram from [Lawrence] Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 11, 1906

div1.p: Reed wires that Moran is employed in Panama, and thus cannot accept a position in Havana.

div1.head: Telegram from [Lawrence] Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 11, 1906
div1.opener:
Form 212. T. W.
Transmitted south No.___________________3____at_____________m. By_______
THE INTERNATIONAL OCEAN TELEGRAPH CO.
To
Kean
This Company TRANSMITS and DELIVERS messages only on conditions limiting its liability, which have been assented to by the sender of the following message.
Errors can be guarded against only by repeating a message back to the sending station for comparison, and the Company will not hold itself liable for errors or delays
in transmission or delivery of Unrepeated Messages, beyond the amount of tolls paid thereon, nor in any case where the claim is not presented in writing within sixty
days after the message is filed with the Company for transmission.
This is an UNREPEATED MESSAGE, and is delivered by request of the sender, under the conditions named above.
ROBERT C. CLOWRY, President and General Manager.
RECEIVED at HAVANA.
42c C. Nx.P. Collect
Panama10
Magoon,
Havana.
6531 11 *NOVRE 1906
div1.p: Moran reemployed here cannot accept position Havana.
div1.closer:
Reed. FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
To Maj Kean

div1.opener:
REPUBLIC OF CUBA
------
UNDER THE PROVISIONAL ADMINISTRATION
OF THE UNITED STATES
---
OFFICE OF THE PROVISIONAL GOVERNOR
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
sw. BRIEF.
Panama, Nov. 11, 1906.
div1.p:
-----Reed
Wires as follows--
“Magoon, Havana. Moran reemployed
here, cannot accept position Havana.”

By order of the Provisional
Governor, respectfully referred
to Major J.R. Kean, U.S.A., Adviser
to the Sanitary Department.
